>>6496701
>>6496725
>The sketch became the lineart and stayed as one layer throughout
I see no wrong in this, exactly my work process.
I do have one question, are you, yourself unsatisfied with your own work flow and results, or do you want thing to look ''cleaner'' because only of outside opinions. Since there's nothing wrong for a piece to have strong or heavy lines. I do think your art has a lot of charm, I really like the bunny guys hair. Of course you can always improve thing like anatomy, gesture and so on. But if you want more cleaner/confident lines, I'd recommend practice line weight, avoid re-drawing lines atop on each other, just do one line at a time and connect them. I also recommend you to to study folds, right now they feel a bit randomly placed, try draw the folds more softer/lighter since it feels like they take the focus away a bit atm.

I felt stupid after I spent so much time putting together that imagine and re-read your request. Like I said in >>6462087, there are books and collections on there worth many thousands of Gallery Points, and you'd hit your limit pretty quickly downloading those via script - anyone would.

On the plus side, it still doesn't cost any money to use a script ... so there is that.

as somone who just started learning the figure using both proko and vilppu simultaneously, it's astounding how different proko's approach to gesture is than vilppus.

Proko constantly says "MOTION NOT CONTOUR" but all his demo videos are him simplifying contours.... then you look at vilppu and you see him making these fluid lines that actually seem related to motion and realize how stiff proko's shit is

desu tho, proko's gesture is much easier for a beg to learn. I still really struggle to do gesture in the same manner as vilppu and this is my third week grinding it.

Learning art of any style is rough. You also need to get used to your materials.
Trad is seen as easier because we've all drawn with pencils and already overcame part of that hurdle.
Basically, starting digital you'll have to learn both drawing AND using tablet/drawing software, so more shit to learn at once. Swapping later to trad is the same as swapping from trad to digital: couple months of getting used to the new tools.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6496876
The jump from trad to digital has its challenges if you go to screenless. But going screen tablet the hurdle is much less. You can get some cheap XP-Pen 16, 13 or 12 screen tablets. I bought the Innovator 16 in 2020 and now they came up with the 2nd Gen 16" tablet which is about half the price of my Innovator 16. (The only downside is the lack of dials). The other hurdles are picking the right color and right shading (if you're worried about messing up your coloring, just eyedrop until you the hang of it).

What you definitely should do is explore your drawing app for shortcuts, key modifiers and templates/auto actions as it could half the amount of time you'd spend working. Eg: I bind the alt button to common tool eraser so I dont need to switch tools to erase at all. It cuts down 1-2 seconds, but it adds up. Ctrl+Shift is for layer select, so I could immediately jump to which layer I want to work on by tapping on the screen instead of layer hunting in the layer window/tool panel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6496876
Consider this: as a /beg/, you're going to need tons of mileage. Hundreds of hours of drawing. With trad, if you carry a sketchpad and pen around with you, you can squeeze in as much sketching as possible. While eating breakfast, in line at the bank, drunk driving down the wrong side of the highway, the possibilities are endless. If you go digital only, you're going to have a set time out of your day where you need to be at your computer doing nothing but drawing. Can you resist the urge to open up a web browser, fap, play vidya, etc.? Do you have a block of your time you can be at your PC? Just something to consider. Otherwise, no, it doesn't really matter, I'm sure there are plenty of successful cartoonists who are primarily digital only.

posts.com:
>>6496876
Starting with digital art as a beginner is not necessarily wrong, but it's important to understand that the skills developed in digital art are not exactly the same as those developed in traditional art. The skills you hone in digital art are centered around the use of software and technology, while traditional art focuses more on fundamental techniques.

However, starting with digital art can be tempting, especially if you're interested in doing cartoon or stylized work, as you can quickly achieve results with the tools available in digital art software.

A potential pitfall of starting digitally is that it can be tempting to rely too heavily on the tools and shortcuts provided by the software, rather than developing your fundamental drawing skills. This can result in a lack of control over the creation process and a lack of understanding of traditional techniques and mediums.

If you do decide to start with digital art, my advice would be to start by learning the traditional techniques and principles of drawing, such as anatomy, perspective, and lighting. This will give you a solid foundation to build upon as you learn the digital tools.

Additionally, consider trying out traditional mediums, such as pencils and charcoal, to help you understand and develop the core skills involved in creating art. This will also give you a more well-rounded skillset and make it easier for you to transition to traditional art down the road, if you so choose.

>>6492190
bring a sketchbook with you wherever you can and try to find little pockets of time to draw in it.

accept that you will never think that you are "good enough" and try to find fun in the process itself and in making improvements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"just draw" is great advice to learn, but if you are practicing and want to make finished pieces, then you can't "just draw". You have to think and decide good things to draw. You can't just draw anything like some redditors here try to say. Drawing random incomprehensible shapes is a waste of your time if you're trying to make something good.

Make a schedule for yourself and turn off all distracts, then when time's up you can put the pencil down and stop worrying. If you end up drawing nothing during that time, then try to come up with a lesson plan or a goal for next time. But that time should be reserved for you sitting in front of the paper to make you used to it.

>>6489241
Yes, it is certainly possible that Kentaro Miura created the character of Guts in Berserk as a form of wish fulfillment. Many artists draw inspiration from their own desires, dreams, and experiences when creating their works. They often use their art as a means of exploring and expressing these desires in a creative and imaginative way.

It's not uncommon for writers, painters, and other creatives to use their art as a way to escape the realities of their lives, and to bring their deepest desires and fantasies to life. This allows them to live vicariously through their characters and to experience things they may not otherwise have the opportunity to experience.

In the case of Berserk, it's likely that Miura was inspired by his own desires and dreams when he created the world and characters of the manga. Guts, with his muscular physique, towering height, and powerful weapons, may represent the idealized self that Miura aspired to become. Similarly, the character of Casca, with her tomboyish attitude and attractive appearance, may represent the kind of partner that Miura wanted by his side.

Whether he was conscious of this or not, the result is a visually rich and highly engaging manga that has captured the hearts and imaginations of millions of readers around the world

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6499208
It's likely that Kentaro Miura was inspired by the themes and stories of mythology and ancient epics when he wrote the Lost Children Arc and the Eclipse in Berserk. Many myths and epics throughout history feature tales of evil, violence, and tragedy, and Miura may have drawn on these stories as a source of inspiration.

For example, the epic of Gilgamesh features themes of power, mortality, and tragedy, and it is possible that Miura was influenced by these themes when he wrote the Eclipse. Similarly, many myths and legends feature stories of gods and heroes battling against evil forces, and this theme is evident in the Lost Children Arc of Berserk.

Also I think it's worth mentioning that the world that these artists lived in at the time of them painting these classical scenes looked like pic related.
They weren't wearing togas and living in forests. They lived in a fairly modern looking world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6493660
Thanks to industrialization, urbanization, and the fertilizer. The population and prosperity of European cities exploded. Now the middle class could afford to buy art and they have different tastes than the historical patrons of arts. So practically anyone with a little bit of training could sustain themselves as an artist. You didn't to go to academies or workshops anymore. You also had other factors like photography and films replacing much of what these art had to to offer. There were also newer opportunities for artists like making posters for products and entertainment.
Basically, the demand for traditional art dried up and the new generations wanted to do their own thing. It's very much like digital illustration vs traditional. Try asking any zoomer if they want to be the next bob ross or james gurney.

>>6493566
Interesting topic. I'd say main reasons are:
- Switch from oil to digital. Usage of oils imposes certain color choices and blending. Digital usually goes for more discrete blends, harsh contrasts, simplified shading, and rare in nature colors.
- The entire modernism purpose was to shift art away from classic subjects and styles. Those styles finally died during 19-20 centuries quest for ugly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Let me preface by saying that I'm talking out of my ass, especially with what concerns historical stuff.
At least in Europe, before WW1, there was a very strong romanticism both for the past and the future, and there was still an innocence to it all.
Now days we live in a post ironic globalized society, where the average person lives a very comfortable, self centered, coomsumer life style, even if in relative poverty.
I feel that the 21st century really killed off any meaningful cultural movement in the western world, and even if you're a nostalgic of those olden days, you can just feel that it's all a facade, the feeling that we're all just pretending doesn't go away I think.

>>6493566
The reason has kind of been touched on a little bit in this thread. You can see the death of classical art play out in the late 1800’s between the academic artists and the pastoral “lower class” artists. Academic Artists lived in such a culturally conservative Christian world because that’s who their patrons were. So much of their genre work, what we recognize as mythological work, was trapped in the past echoing the same pre approved themes and stories from the Greek and biblical accounts. The work was stale. Take bouguereau for example. The absolute pinnacle of artistic ability but his work is mostly boring as fuck from an emotional or narrative view. The early impressionists we’re addressing that lack of meaning by making work that was real to them and had to do with the world they lived in. It was mostly great for a while but then motherfucking Picasso came along with his god damned cubism and then everyone stopped giving a fuck about the quality of the craftsmanship and wanted work that was more of the pure emotional state and less of the representation of what the emotion was derived from. The fauvists were high as shit. The late impressionists all had heavy metal poisoning from lead white and fake absinthe. The dadaists jumped the shark. The cult of personality period in the 60’s and 70’s was a blur of coke and ether. The naive artists tried to bring the art world back down to earth. Brutalists didn’t survive the 80’s. Album posters were the only real art in the 90’s. 2000’s were a joke. Now everyone is suddenly an illustrator/graffiti artist and acrylic flows like water. We are trying so hard to recover the identity that was lost. Thankfully ateliers are becoming way more popular but they still lack the ability to teach depth and emotion in art. The west doesn’t have a cultural identity or narrative that people resonate with, and we don’t even like each other that much right now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6493566
This is classicism. Its roots are in the art and culture of ancient Greece, as passed on to the Romans and then to Christianized Europe. The art is not "realism," and was NOT displaced by photography. It is idealized. The figures are not individuals, but ideal "types" that follow proportional canons. Forms are simplified and monumentalized, and accidental or distracting details are omitted. Also, violent perspective, with its size distortion, is not a part of this art. Foreshortening does appear, but more so in the baroque offshoot. Classical art favors a depiction of the human figure in which the parts are seen in their true forms and relationships, and the posing of figures reflects that.
The subject matter was Greek myth, and later Biblical stories and historical events, all rendered in the classical style. Accuracy in historical costuming, accessories and architecture was valued. Educated people were familiar with the subject matter of classical art; it was a shared cultural heritage.
The historical changes that brought industrialization, communism and two world wars sounded the death knell of classicism. The old order was seen as standing in the way of "progress," and needing to be overturned. The audience for this kind of art mostly disappeared. Modern "classical realism" is not classical except perhaps in technique. It isn't idealized, nor does it portray classical subject matter.

>>6482485
going digital is one of your problems, not that its digital, but because you have no idea how digital works.
1. use an anti-aliased brush, as in a brush that is pure pixels
2. stop using gray or black to shade. when you drew that first one did you shade with a gray marker? no? of course not, they dont exist, you shaded by having the same value, just more vibrant and deeper, not blacker.
3. stop shading entirely, shading is a beg trap and is its own study.
4. work on line-weight, notice how in your first drawing there are bits of intense thick lines and parts where its nice and soft, your new one has all the same line, and its all not working.
5. stop sketching, first draft is the final draft.
its like your raw shapes are fine, its just that nothing else is working with it, the boots and legs are nice, you just botched it all with that grey half-assed coloring and trying to emulate le nippon artists instead of trying to draw what feels good. anime is a solved medium, either fall in line or make your own feel.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6497442
>my goals are to draw cute anime girls or whatever
>I can't even copy art right
if you're prioritizing copying, then you're on the right track already. doing fundamentals on the side is good, too (e.g. anatomy). the more fundamentals you know, the better you'll be able to learn from copying others. you can understand the their decision making process better, and their choices in abstraction.

if you're frustrated with your copying but can't say why, then you probably just need to work on developing a critical eye and bettering your accuracy (in addition to your mechanical skills if that's part of the problem). you have to get good at identifying what's wrong, and then fixing that. as long as it looks "wrong" to you, you can figure out why. think hard and compare carefully. be as specific as possible. be as specific as you know how to be. the self-improvement loop is:
>create art
>critique it (what's wrong with it, specifically?)
>use critique to identify specific weaknesses (e.g. "these hands look wrong")
>study and practice hard to patch these specific weaknesses you identified (e.g. draw 1000 hands from ref)
>repeat

you'll get better at critiquing yourself productively the better your fundamentals get, too. there are a lot of clever study techniques for improving in specific ways, but if you just do studies and never create art, you will get bored and burned out. likewise, if you just make shit and never critique and study, you will get frustrated with lack of progress. you have to join them together.

>>6496759
>no reason/attention
I wont deny the attention part. I am like all the other 99% art fags: the more fame the better! BUT you act like reading multiple beg books is waste of time or something. It isnt. It allowed me to comprehend why there are so many clashing advice regarding drawing. Its because there are roughly three distinct paths: gesture, observation and construction. All three ultimately leads to the same end result, but the way you get there is mad different. I wouldnt know this if i didnt do multiple beg books. They all teach the same but sometimes the diff between approaches and mindset is like day and night.

what does that mean?

understanding that you have a problem simplifying is helpful. if you feel overwhelmed by detail/complexity, try zooming out mentally and working from the biggest shapes you see to the smallest. if you get the largest proportions, angles and relationships right at the outset, you can work your way down into finer detail more confidently. reducing problems to smaller, solvable chunks is good advice for problem solving in general; but with drawing and painting, smaller, simpler problems usually mean bigger, more abstract shapes.

enveloping is a good way to do this, starting from the beginning. picrel is a crappy envelope I drew on your ref. I'm a retard but it helps me a lot. here are some videos I skimmed but they seem legit enough to get the idea across:

>>6496152
Here are some steps to help you learn color theory and apply it to your art:

1. Study the basics of color theory: Start by learning about the color wheel, color harmonies, and the properties of colors, such as hue, saturation, and brightness.

2. Experiment with colors: Use a color wheel and different media to experiment with color combinations and see how colors interact with each other.

2. Practice color mixing: Try mixing colors to create new shades and tints, and learn how to create different color schemes, such as complementary, monochromatic, and analogous.

3. Observe color in real life: Study the colors in nature, architecture, and everyday objects to gain a better understanding of how colors work together in the real world.

4. Use references: Study the work of artists you admire and see how they use color in their art. This can help you understand how to create moods, evoke emotions, and create depth in your own artwork.

5. Apply what you’ve learned: Start incorporating color theory into your artwork by planning color schemes, experimenting with different color combinations, and making color a conscious part of your creative process.

6. Keep practicing: The more you practice, the better you will become at using color in your art. Don’t be afraid to make mistakes, as this is a natural part of the learning process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
AI art's real cool ability would be to streamline animation processes.

Imagine instead of drawing 2400 pictures, you just did spot work on same pictures, and every time you did the work got more to what you would draw. Like you just put in character sheets, (mapped to every angle, like the 3d presentation of 2d art) built standard packs to understand drawn rules about hair or accessories to a basic extent, and over time with improvement it figured out what you wanted. All that time spent on inbetweens spent on just making the finished product.

That sounds cool, that sounds like a benefit to animation. Programs that can help to speed up the craft, leave people more time to make more material, that's the net benefit. It'd be like getting mad we don't use printing presses with specific blocks anymore for printing that you have to take out by hand and swap and shit, typing a prompt into a computer is still an action of an individual, it's still the performance of crafting, it's still art you made with your actions.

hold the looking at camera frame for longer before transitioning into the forward leaning motion also make the head a bit farther back in that frame or push it slightly forward in the final pose cuz if you're leaning forward you bend forward slightly rather than rotation forward while being stuck in the same location
also do the eyes completely open first and add the blink after you've smoothened the movement
i get the vibe you're going for but i think you over-stepped in that bit
as is anime eyes are already notoriously difficult to place properly since their orientation depends on the camera angle rather than some defined points in space

you have long way to grow young grass-hopper

The first several frames should look like a ball (yours appears out of nowhere at speed)

It should not slow out from the bounce, so try removing a few frames after the impact
You have blank frames, which is causing blinking; clean it up
As the ball approaches its apex, it should slow down because of gravity, so add more frames. At the top of its bounce it should become its roundest

Why you should not trust youtube shills:

If you have any additional questions, ask them.
Remember to ignore all chinese shills.

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

>>6494233
I have an Artisul D16 (not pro) that I bought for about 300 of my local pesos a few years ago that I only just started using properly a few months ago when I started learning digital painting very seriously. It's a 15.6 inch screen drawing tablet.
I have been very fortunate that it doesn't seem to have any hardware issues (some scary reviews out there lmao) so far, but holy sweet mother does its software suck.
Coming from an ancient wacoom bamboo from like 2012 I just cannot believe how bad the software is. In general I am extremely grateful that the tablet was so cheap because I was that guy who thought that a screen less one would be just as good but let me tell you now that I've seen the light I can never go back.
The problem is that the D16's drivers are being held together with duct tape and cum and it just barely works even having lots of strange issues like I can't use the two side buttons on the pen because pressing one even for a second will remap the stylus to half way between my main monitor and the d16 display which I sometimes can't even fix upon several restarts of the computer. Loads of little headaches and setting it up for left handed use was hell.

Basically I never want another Chinese tablet again. I'm still running windows 10 and the driver to this tablet hasn't been updated since 2018 so I am mentally preparing myself for this tablet to just stop working when I'm forced to upgrade to win11 probly within the next year.
I dont use pen tilt and I've found that 15.6 inches I about all the space I have on my tiny desk and so far I haven't found that I wished the tablet was bigger (only that it worked better).
I have no idea about any of this tech stuff but all I want is a functional tablet with good software and support. I dont use pen tilt or even need buttons on the tablet (I have a keyboard). Because if this I'm heavily leaning to a less feature packed Wacom. I really don't want to buy used. Any ideas?

I'm trying to draw a sci-fi landscape, and I finished the main sketch, for which I used freehand perspective and common sense. Granted, it looks like shit. So I wanted to correct the perspective, but I don't know what I'm supposed to do to prevent skewness of the image?

I know you're supposed to fit the image in the cone of vision, like Erik Olson said. But when the vanishing points are too close, it looks too skewed. And when they are far, it looks... kinda isometric and not so 3D. So what are you supposed to do when you want to clean up your sketch?

I tried eyeballing the perspective but it takes a lot of time and it just isn't worth it. There must be a way to balance out the vanishing points so that it works? Or maybe I'm supposed to see lines that don't align because I'm using actual perspective on the new iteration of the drawing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Exhibit 1 - 3 vanishing points. One up for height, and 2 for a standard 2 point perspective. They are far away from eachother, and the blocks look 2D

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Exhibit 2 - same vanishing points, but closer to the image. Lens skewness now seems to be more present.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6496715
Take what I say with a grain of salt, I haven't studied perspective that carefully.
The amount of skew gives the viewer a sense of distance from the object.
https://e-hentai.org/s/7f21447ae5/2170768-124
So the amount you choose is really up to you, to create a sense of scale for the viewer.
>>6496720
By doing this you are modifying the horizon line, which suggests the camera is tilted. If you wanted to do it without tilting the camera you could try moving the top vanishing point to change the triangle (between vanishing points).
https://e-hentai.org/s/f2816ccf42/2170768-115
>>6496717
The horizon line also has extra meaning, everything that intersects it is at the same height (eye level).
https://e-hentai.org/s/ee67fd1958/2170768-12
So in this image, you're saying that all those parts of the structure are waist-height.

If I were trying to solve this, I would try choosing the vanishing points with a simpler stack of boxes instead of bits of the complicated structure first. Good luck anon.

I'll start of by saying, I've never studied advanced perspective. All the things I know I found out by intuition or trying things out, so no idea if it's entirely correct. Regarding closeness of vanishing points I find that it's determined by how close the object is to the viewer. Hold up a shoe box really close to your face then look at a big building from far away. Both are gonna have around the same size but the shoebox's edges are gonna be much more skewed. So when it comes to choosing how close your VPs are gonna be, there's no wrong answer it just depends on how close you want the object to be. Pic related demonstrates what I mean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6496818
Now, how would I handle composition similar to yours (one where the camera's panning up)? Firstly, I need something to ground everything in the scene, normally this will be the ground plane but since we can't see it I'll use the character. I determine where I want to place him in the scene, using a box or square to indicate this, then I find his VPs. I then use these point to plot out the rest of the objects in the scene. Finally, I draw the actual objects. I suggest you start out drawing scenes with a more top down view, since seeing the ground makes it a lot easier to plot out the figures.

posts.com:
>>6495263
Whichever you want to do, the first step is to write the story/scenario. Once you have a final draft (or very close to it) you can start working on the artwork- character design, setting, wardrobes, hairstyles, etc. Once you have decided on final designs, it helps to make a reference sheet of each major character so you can draw them consistently (VERY important). Next, you do storyboards or thumbnails which have little detail but allow you to plot out each panel/scene in advance. Once you're happy with that, you can start doing the pencils, where you essentially draw the final image in a loose, sketchy form which is refined in the next step... which is inking. Inking is where you determine lineweight, line quality as well as other things to produce a clean looking outline of your characters, backgrounds, etc. If your comic is in black and white, you can keep it as is or add screentones to increase the illusion of 3 dimensionality. If you want to color, this is where you do so. Finally, you can do the speech bubbles and dialogue followed by sound effects. Congrats, you just made a comic!
As you can tell, it's a lot of work which is why it's very time consuming and difficult for a single person to produce a work on par with major or even indie studios. I entered the call to action webtoons contest last year and it took me a little under two months to produce ~60 pages, working 40 hours a week. And even after all that work, [spoiler]it still looked like some major /beg/ shit.[/spoiler] I'm happy I did it though because I learned a lot and it definitely improved my skills. Animation is a whole other beast and a lot more work than comics.

>>6476156
I've been a professional illustrator for 20 years now.
I used Photoshop for around 10 years for my work. Besides that I only tried other software for fun (Painter, PaintToolSAI, etc.).
When I started to work on some comics related projects I decided to try CSP (Still called Manga Studio at the time), because a few art friends said it had nice tools for drawing line-art.
It was love at first sight, because of it's pencils/inks brush engine and the feel of the brushes. CSP has the ability to use your stroke speed as a line thickness modifier and it allowes me to rotate my canvas (photoshop introduced that feature later on but it's crap to this day), which at the time was a game changer for me (check pic attached). Photoshop simply couldn't compete anymore for natural/traditional looking line-art.
At first I still used Photoshop for coloring and painting my line drawings, but then I completely moved away from it and fully switched to CSP.

CSP pros (vs Photoshop):
- much better line art brushes and engine
- canvas rotation (photoshop with his inertia thing is total crap)
- better color mixing brushes
- better perspective and ruler tools (out of the box at least)
- more stable (I haven't used Photoshop seriously in almost a decade, so this might have changed)
- cheaper

CSP cons (vs Photoshop):
- doesn't support modern multi core processors (when I switched to CSP back in the day, this wasn't an issue, since Photoshop was a resources consuming always crashing mess)
- more limited for custom brushes that involve painting

>>6476156
Long text well about my experiences with PS vs CSP
If you're new to digital art, I would still learn this first as this will force you to learn the brush system and all the basics. If you know Photoshop, you know everything. You can literally get hired at lots of places for just being able to show you can use Photoshop well.
People say that CSP runs faster but I don't think this is true. Unoptimized CSP runs faster, but if you just google "Photoshop 60 fps" "Making Photoshop Faster" from Borodante or KNKL you'll find that Photoshop can fully utilize multithreaded machine setups. Even with higher end PC builds, I've noticed Photoshop runs faster than CSP, even after tweaking settings for both. For some reason the cursor on Photoshop just tracks directly behind your pen much more accurately than CSP by a tiny margin, whereas CSP you have to do extensive fuckery to get that to be the close to the same.
For CSP The Pen pressure is more customizable meaning I have more options for line brushes and adjusting things. This is not as big of an advantage as you'd think though as for PS the Pen pressure control out of the box works great already, whereas in CSP you usually have to fuck around for a bit to get it feel right. Usually I end up changing all my pens to a straight or slight curve and make everything dependent on my tablet curve pressure anyway.
I still use CSP mainly for 2 reasons:
The program is constantly getting better and better, whereas the newer versions of Photoshop is actually getting worse than CS6 for painting artwork. With the future updates, it will surpass PS
CSP EX has a built in storyboarding feature that is extremely valuable for organizing and making a workflow for making manga/comics and an industry level animation timeline workflow. I've only ever dabbled in those, but I like the feeling that if I ever wanted to make personal projects CSP already has me covered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456218
I had a similar issue and it might sound retarded but try going the exact opposite direction and take some time aside to do whatever you think would be the most miserable, unfun exercise. For me that was copying a Bargue plate. By the end of it you won't have burst into flames and even if it takes way longer than it should've or looks horrible it's not the end of the world and you'll have gotten something out of the experience.
After doing that I became progressively more ok with the idea of doing studies even though I used to be super averse to the very idea of drawing copies since you're going through all that trouble just to reproduce something that's already there. I understood the value theoretically but had no fucking patience to subject myself to it. Sitting down to study and analyze a picture can actually end up being really fun, specially if it's an artist you like. To me this was unthinkable because the only way I had fun before was making shit up and tossing the drawing as soon as I got bored.
Just pick one thing and stick with it, the more you do it the more used you'll get to it. For me, at least, the problem was that I was too used to drawing mindlessly as recreation so studying felt unnatural and scary. It's just a matter of getting used to something unfamiliar.
Again I know it's retardedly simple but I think it's the most reliable solution. Just be consistent with it and eventually the aversion will be gone. You'll always have plenty of time to draw your own stuff for fun, and it'll expand your options.

posts.com:
Either find what you like drawing, get out of a comfort zone, experiment by fucking with different media/styles, or find something else entirely. Even if you might be good at it, it may still not be a fit because you don't like it. For example I'm great at the physical and mental aspects of my work, but there's so much bureaucratic paperwork horseshit associated that it sucks all joy I might have from it.

Art as a profession is something one should take joy in otherwise while the skill may remain, the soul goes away. Art as something for yourself doesn't need to worry about it, and if you don't enjoy it, much as I hate the word, you're just being a poser for likes and (You)s.

Do what you love anon. Draw what you love, draw who you love

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451437
Practice, simple as.
When I did go to an art school for a bit, I went in expecting to be amongst titans, but I still ended up being a big fish in a small pond, mostly because I've been drawing for longer than most have been alive there.
You just gotta do it over and over again, until eventually you can internalize steps and externally "skip" them, so instead of doing the rough skeleton, your able to go straight to rough details and all of that.
At one point I just went hard mode and exclusively used ball point pen to draw, so no pencil roughs to erase later, just try to make it look good in one go, results turned out to about pic related.
Just practice practice practice

Find the gesture, and exaggerate it. say their torso is bent to the right, and they are in sort of a ( shape, exaggerate that, push their hips more to the left, and the top torso to the right. I think I might be too dumb to learn perspective.
I'm practicing perspective to learn to draw scenarios according to Dong Ho Kim's Space Drawing Perspective book, at some point it tells us to practice with real photographs and try to identify the vanishing points and practice drawing it.
Easy enough, I can put the vanishing points at eye level and sketch the general scenario, but when I'm trying to add detail, I realize that there are objects in the scenario that don't fit the existing vanishing points, and rather they seem to have their own, so I must have missed these vanishing points at the beginning, and then I get overwhelmed. Am I inherently retarded, or what am I doing wrong?

For example, picrel, it immediately jumps to me as a one point perspective, squarely centered, that's why I chose it, it was easy, but then look at the chairs on the floor or the bench near the camera, if I try to draw them in this one point perspective they become all wonky, so there's another point I'm missing, so I put another point in the horizon, but now the whole piece has two perspective points, so it must be a two point perspective, but now then the scenario becomes wonky if I try to fit it.
Or is it that there's TWO one point perspectives? How does that happen? Am I overthinking it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6481188
In that picture with the table im sure youll find that theres three points of perspective. Yes there can be more then one and thats our reality. The first perspective you lay down is more or less the bases for the hallway and the other two perspectives are helpful for the furniture. Because furniture does not always align with the first vanishing point
Im still a beg when it comes to perspective myself and the confusion is part of the learning process. I cant find a pic that truly shows what im trying to say but I found one that shows two points indoors. Indoor perspective is tricky.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479906
It's a good start, but I'd approach it from a few different angles. Your pic helps sketch out composition, basic values, and is quick.

I'd also learn perspective, design, dive deeper into color and value, and do studies/plein airs to learn more about light and nuance of everything in nature.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6489246
First you got to figure out what you want to draw.
Example: If you want to draw a dragon, draw a dragon, if it doesn't come out well then look for references. Then after a few studies try to draw the dragon again with out references.
Then replace dragon with whatever you actually want.

posts.com:
I've been lifting for almost 2 years now, and I noticed my hands have changed from slender and soft to rough and thick(er).
I also [feel] like my fingers are slightly more stiff, I think would be the right word, and now I'm seriously considering stopping weight lifting and transitioning to a strictly cardio/bodyweight routine because I fear that it's negatively impacting my capability to draw.

Might sound retarded, I know, but hear me out. First of all, the skin on my hands feel more like leather than the weakling hands I used to have, and we all know that's a lot less bendy. When I do excercises to prevent carpal tunnel, the same ones I've always done, the fingers feel more cumbersome, slower, stiffer, thicker. I believe this is bad for drawing, since dextrous and nimble fingers with fine function and accuracy would be preferred.
Now you might say that even if you entertained my lunacy, that it would still be negligible, but if I'd rather be a weak retard that can draw well than a jacked retard taht can draw pretty well.
A 5% decrease in output quality in return for large muscles would be met with a swift "No" from me.

It also struck me that I don't usually see big burly guys with big burly hands draw intricate things often, if ever.
Is cardio the artist way? Thoughts?

Why are my drawings so much more soulful when I draw them while I should be doing something else more important?
Most of my favorite drawings are ones I've done while in class or when it's late and should go to bed or some shit.
And even though I can see the mistakes, I still feel happy with the overall result.
They feel "soulful".
Meanwhile, drawings I do during my free time I set to draw and practice, they usually have fewer mistakes and that's not always the case, but they feel so dull and lifeless.

My guess is that when I draw when something important is going on, I draw smaller things in concept, which my ability is enough to make something good of, meanwhile when I give myself time I try big projects that I don't have the ability to do correctly yet, so the mistakes are bigger.
But somebody else has this problem?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6498386
It's common for artists to feel more creative and inspired when they are not focusing on their art in a deliberate way. The pressure to perform or produce something perfect can often stifle creativity and result in less soulful work. On the other hand, when you are drawing while you should be doing something else, you are likely less focused on the outcome and more in tune with the creative process, which allows you to produce more spontaneous and expressive work.

Another factor could be that when you are drawing smaller, simpler drawings, you may be less self-conscious and able to let your instincts guide you, which can result in a more soulful result. Meanwhile, when you try to tackle bigger projects, you may become more critical of your work, causing you to second-guess your instincts and produce less inspired drawings.

>>6497806
I recommend grouping values to make things less muddy. It could help to start with bigger shapes and two values first (your main light and shadow) then go into the smaller details and more nuanced values later. Another way to clean it up would be paying more attention to your edge control. To me it seems as if you went first with a small brush, which would explain the white spaces, but you don't seem to have a clear image of what the final product would look like.

I agree with the guy that a two stone study would be good but I don't know if I would agree with treating your current progress as an underpainting because the layers look very rough and thick to me the more you add the more uneven it will become. This was my mistake with my first oil painting 4 years ago. Instead of knowing how to take away from the paint and be decisive with my actions, I kept adding more over my mistakes up only to end up with my layers, texture, surface, and brushstrokes all fucked up so I had to use my thinner to wipe layers of wasted paint and repaint over after destroying all the preexisting paint. Thinking you can just correct your mistakes by painting over like with digital is a common mistake for people painting for the first time.

I also don't know if I would agree with the comment on warm tones, because temperature is more advanced than values. If you don't know your light and shadows adding more varied temperature will most likely make things even more confusing (mistake I do a lot the time). I recommend a zorn palette for temperature work, but I myself am terrible at temperature so I really can't give any advice beyond the basics and beginner stuff.

Just like it took you 7 to 8 years to learn a good attitude to create art while enjoying the process. You have to learn to enjoy the process of making comics,games,ect. These things are diffucult tasks which take effort to create. I believe you are on the right track. Keep trying and thinking on how to achieve your goals in a healthy way. Plus remember you need to get to a high enough skill level where your creations naturally comeout. If its frustrating you, re-evaluate the goal and lower it to a skill level thats appropriate. So with comic making, if you get stuck on a full story, do a short story, and if you get stuck on a short story, do a one page scene. Keep lowering the bar till you can do that goal, and complete it, even on a bad day. Then build up from there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6499286
It's important to acknowledge the progress you've made and celebrate your growth as an artist. It's also common for people to lose motivation on projects, especially when they're related to their passions. To overcome this, it may help to identify what specific elements of a project are causing boredom or burnout, and finding ways to make those parts more interesting or manageable. Additionally, setting realistic goals and breaking projects down into smaller, manageable steps can help keep motivation levels high. It's also okay to take breaks and focus on other aspects of your life if you're feeling overwhelmed. Overall, it's a process of trial and error, so don't be too hard on yourself and keep experimenting until you find what works for you.

Go for it man. I've studied with people who became successful artists starting at the age of 40 or 50, all the cynicism here is a meme. The field is hard but if you work at it and really think about the work you're doing and who it's for you can definitely find a niche.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483080
You can work out foreshortening using a geometrical method called parallel projection. It entails first drawing a simple view, then projecting parallel lines from various points on the figure at a desired angle to construct a second view. Sometimes, as in picrel, one or more intermediary steps are required to get the desired end result. Picrel is from Jean Cousin's Livre de Portraiture, which contains many examples. You can also find a few simple (one-step) examples of this method in Burne Hogarthe's Dynamic Figure Drawing. It shows up mostly in older books, though.
Note: This method does not give you size/camera distortion, only foreshortening. For the former, you need to set up a picture plane and have your projecting lines converge towards a point representing the eye of the viewer.
This is all fascinating but I don't recommend it. When it takes more than one step, it's an enormous amount of labor; furthermore, it's difficult to predict the end result. It is better to work intuitively and train your eye to what looks right. If you insist on perfect accuracy, using a 3D model as the basis for your drawing would achieve the same result and save you a lot of time.

>>6483080
>I know there's a scientific mathe formula

well if you really want to torture yourself...

Bruce MacEvoy's Handprint has one of the most comprehensive explanations of perspective anywhere on the web:
https://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/tech10.html#index

Wade Meyers is an aviation artist who uses descriptive geometry for all of his aircraft drawings & renderings. 2d plan drawings are required to construct objects this way. You also have to already understand the basic mathematics of perspective in the previous link to understand anything he's saying:
https://www.wademeyersstudios.com/book/1774/perspective-projection-by-descriptive-geometry-a-manual-for-the-artist
There are other introductions to descriptive geometry but this one is made for aviation and vehicle artists specifically.

Willy A. Bartschi's "Linear Perspective" book gives you an history of linear perspective, its applications, and also the "circle of view" method.
https://archive.org/details/linearperspectiv0000bart/mode/2up
I think this is the best introduction to formal perspective.

But like everyone else in this thread is saying, technical perspective is going to give you a headache if all you want to do is construct foreshortened figures. It would be much easier just to learn the basic freehand perspective that everyone teaches.
This stuff is really only necessary if you want to create technical drawings, drawings with really accurate measurements, industrial design, architecture... etc.. but in those fields descriptive geometry has already been superseded by CAD and 3D software which do all the thinking for you.

posts.com:
>>6484333
No problem. It is good to know these things, because technical perspective applies to more than just 2d art. 3D software runs off of the same mathematical foundation, and photography is a quite literal representation of the projection plane and camera, so the same composition techniques apply.

Like >>6483111 was saying, distortion and foreshortening can be achieved with technical perspective techniques. Remember that you can change your field of view in the same way as you can with a camera.

The "circle of view" method of perspective described by Bartschi is also incorporated in a more digestible form in Scott Robertson's "How to Draw," he calls it "cone of vision" but they're functionally the same thing.
Here's a youtube video that summarizes it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RsbzCHLsQuQ

Regarding "How to Draw," later in the book Robertson decides to only do the tedious method of subdividing squares diagonally over and over again to build forms in perspective. Just doing perspective projection with plan views for complex forms would have been easier. Do that instead for hard-surface shit.

I don't think people are "hiding" any secret technique on how to foreshorten. Art education in technical perspective collapsed after abstract art, and then descriptive geometry suffered a massive blow when CAD and 3D software phased it out of higher education (Back in the day architecture schools had professors solely dedicated to teaching descriptive geometry).

Most people are only capable of teaching lazy methods of foreshortening because that's all they've ever known, and without any accessible knowledge on the subject people just brute-force their way into it, iterating over and over again until their perspective or foreshortening looks sound. And because they've never been taught any technical knowledge, they have no vocabulary to describe what they're doing, so most "tutorials" just boil down to
>yeah just uh make it bigger when its closer

posts.com:
>>6487536
Not commenting on his work (not familiar with it). But from this tutorial, I can tell you he is needlessly overcomplicating the subject, and also presenting questionable "facts," such as there being "6 vanishing points in total." In fact, any set of parallel lines that inclines away from the picture plane will have a vanishing point, and the number of vanishing points will depend on how many such sets of lines are inclined at angles different from all the others. The vanishing points could be on the horizon line, above or below it. You could have hundreds or thousands of vanishing points in a single image (imagine a disorganized heap of Legos, each with its own sets of vanishing points).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6486547
Prior to 3D modeling being widely available, if you wanted to (for example) create game assets from an oblique overhead view, this geometric method would allow you to set a viewing angle (say, 60 degrees) in relation to the ground plane, and construct all your frames of character animation, as well as objects and scenery, and have everything be consistently foreshortened throughout. Part of the reason I'm familiar with this stuff is because I once tried it as an experiment, animating a character in 8 directions with an idle stance and 6-frame run cycle. It is extremely labor intensive but it does work. With human figures, there is still a lot of artistic intuition involved. The geometry will give you different points but a human body is not a rectangular prism; you still have to draw it yourself.
I guess what I'm saying is, some types of drawing have the requirements of both art and math, as in my game example, wherein it was necessary to maintain consistency among multiple frames of animation/directions of movement in difficult foreshortening. But using this method for regular illustration would be counterproductive and would suck the life out of your drawing.

>>6487867
The goal for Guilty Gear animations is to mimic hand-drawn 2d anime, down to the imperfections. All the frames are hand crafted poses and parts are often tweaked and distorted per frame. If they'd just slapped on a distorting lens and not destroyed the figure it wouldn't look nearly as convincing and comes across as quite stiff.

That's kind of the benefit of not sticking to a really strict formula, even when just drawing. "Winging it" requires some form of understanding of perspective but then deciding to break those rules or to say "fuck it" if the result is way more dynamic and appealing.

you've to train your mind for it. Its super imposing imagination type where you super impose your imaginary creations onto your visual feed. I recommend imagining smaller things first because bigger the imaginary object hold on your visual feed, harder it is to imagine it. I recommend avoiding video games, sleeping late, sleeping less then 10 hours, social media consumption and anything that would dull your mind. Even reading books for long can dull your mind. From my experience the sharpest my mind ever have been where I've been drawing *without* references and having very long walks in the wild while also working out

Types of imagination:
imagining without the visual feed: type of when you daydream or read books. People refer to this when they talk about imagination

super imposed imagining (one you want to venture to): imagining an apple on your palm. imagining that apple interacting with the real world. Making a real world object in your visual feed transform (making a tree fall. a car crash etc...)

you can start with small creations like bugs flying around then venture into more advanced stuff

>>6483080
If you're looking for advanced resources on perspective and figure drawing, I recommend the following:

1. Andrew Loomis' "Drawing the Head and Hands" - This book goes into great detail on the subject of drawing heads and hands in perspective, and is widely considered a classic in the field.

2. Scott Robertson's "How to Draw" - This book covers a wide range of subjects, including perspective, and is highly regarded for its in-depth and practical approach.

3. Proko's Figure Drawing Fundamentals course - This online video course covers all aspects of figure drawing, including perspective, and is taught by well-known instructor Stan Prokopenko.

4. The New Masters Academy - This online school offers a wide range of courses on drawing and painting, including a course on advanced perspective that covers the mathematics and science behind it.

These resources should provide you with a solid foundation in advanced perspective, and help you apply it to your dynamic figure drawing.

Fair point, I did started drawing from a relatively young age. But I'm joining 30 soon.
It's not that I don't understand your concern anon(s), I truly empathise with you. Between adult responsibility and trying to learn art, it can be a frustrating experience to try something you like and only see little progress.
Still, if you don't mind me offering some advice, perhaps you can consider trying a new mindset to art?

Because to be fair, I'm sure many artist also struggle with the inferiority complex, seeing many skilled and talented artist around them producing better art.
Starting early in art simply mean I was able to get past that mental cage sooner compare to those who started late. Everyone goes through it, and the time it take vary differently per person. Your road will inherently be different compared to your peers. So take comfort in your journey and try to have fun with what little time you have available.

>I will never get over the feeling of disappointment I have at myself constantly playing catch up.

If it's any consolation, that feeling never really go away. It just hurt a little less. There will always be your peer who outperform you in many ways. The most painful part is knowing you both start exactly in the same starting line. But while he's performing and getting the attention he deserve, you're left behind watching him from the back. So chin up anon. You can do it.

>>6463841
I got in the industry by founding my own gaming company with colleagues and being employed there with an artist role. So not really your typical way of getting into the industry, but definitely one with the brightest future I would say. Would recommend over chasing jobs and clients your whole career.
But if you want to get into the industry, don't send the same portfolio to dozens of clients. Tailor it to their needs, show them that you want to do the "dirty" jobs as well. For example, if you want to do concept art, don't just put up flashy images of soldiers (they got enough people who want to do that) but rather lots of concepts for mundane objects that will fill their game world. But really, it depends on what kind of industry you want to get into

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6493866
confidence is key when making art. if you're hesitant with your forms you'll end up with hard to read pictures. when you choose a focal point in the picture, really focus on making the forms there clear, don't be afraid to use ambient occlusion to emphasise the form. also work on your flow, even if your study doesn't have a clear flow of focus, make it up in your digital painting.

>>6493762
to call hesitancy impressionism is kind of a miss, impressionist masters were very intentional and confident in their painting. you can do it digitally too if your process and post-process is done well

Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8
Krenz Accuracy Imgs: https://files.catbox.moe/tklkj8.rar

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Recommended Resources:
https://pastebin.com/Yz2scAEc

I run an etsy shop with my roommates, one of them had a button press and we're all artists so it seemed like the logical next step. We then bought a printer and then bought sticker paper. Vograce seems to be the go to recommendation for charm manufacturing, but I wouldn't trust that considering they're the DEFAULT recommendation and most people are very secretive about their actual manus.

Go check out the artist alley general on /cgl/, that's essentially dedicated discussion to that sort of thing when they're not being catty af about other artists.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Last place I worked (not art related) we went through a marketting company, they did stuff like hats, bags, pins, stickers, the typical kind of merch you would see at a botique. We just provided the art assets and picked what we wanted to sell, did some back and forth after checking out samples then talked amounts and pricing (my job). Most of the stuff from there is outsourced to china/se asia then shipped back to the states where we would sell it. You could go that route, or take a chance and try to contact a manufacturer (look into white label). Upside to the marketting company was we didn't have to deal with the actual production, didn't need to get any equipment and had a solid go to in case there were problems. Downside is the price (for a single person or small team) and minimum orders and storage.
If you want to make your own merch from scratch you'll start from the ground up.
Depending on where you live there may be a local shop who would do this stuff for you.

>>6494706
I'd have trouble shifting gears from work to draw and back.
Like with sleep. I do not take my phone to bed or have a tv going because thats bed. With drawing. the art room or desk you draw on should be for drawing. I do have some video games around me, and that can't be avoided to to the space I live in, but I have more art books and comics around me than games.

I sit there and look at them for about 30 mins or so. Soak in it until it moves me to draw. Like chick that imprints on its mother, maybe there is some primal part that is born and dies throught the day and when I sit to draw, I'm making that primal subconscious part of me say "Hey, I draw, I will draw now."

Finally, the gear has shifted, and my subconscious is now in line with my conscious.

>>6490586
Thanks
He had ESP as a child, but lost it during some MK-Ultra-like experiments. They didn't seem particularly traumatic at the time, but he has lost his ESP since and feels that emptiness or gap ever since it was taken away from him.

He's very withdrawn and spends most of his time reading books, seeking forbidden knowledge on the dark web (I know it's a meme, but it's in more of a cyberpunk setting), doing parkour, and observing people from hiding spots. Hiding and parkour are about the only things he's good at, but is reasonably tech-savvy.

He's also not amazing in a fight, but his strength lies in setting up traps and stealthy takedowns. His weapon is a pair of brass knuckles if he does need to fight.

He basically just wants answers as to what the nature of his powers were when he was a kid, why they were taken, what impact it has on the country, etc. and infiltrates CIA facilities for this knowledge (and maybe some cool gear). The further he digs, the more dangerous it becomes. But what does he have to lose?

What is /ALT/?
If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.
>Rules & Guidelines
(1) Any form of cartooning is welcome; so submit and receive feedback from others. (2) Please resize your images before posting. (3) Share your knowledge and (4) Remember to not be afraid of asking for critique. Most importantly, keep discussion at a civil level
>I came for anime. Why does the image OP say cartoons general?
To distinguish from the anime study thread (janitor supported). Please post your studies there and personal work goes here.

>Community Resources

>>6499384
Yeah, I really can't think of a use of AI for "study reference" that isn't already better accomplished through existing resources. Why trust the AI to generate "nude woman in 3/4 view" when you can find actual photos of a real nude woman in 3/4 view? And similarly, if you had a live-in live model, you'd ask them to post for you and not have to rely on somebody else's photos. Want to learn a style? Find pro art done in that style and similar styles. I'm amused by the resident "tradchad" painters who apparently wants to reduce their art to the manual labor of copying AI slop to a canvas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dynamic Sketching by Peter Han: This book covers the basics of sketching and inking, including line weight and design, with a focus on capturing motion and dynamic compositions.

The Art of Inking by Bob Almond: This book covers the techniques and tools of inking, with a focus on using inking to enhance and communicate emotions.

How to Draw Comics the Marvel Way by Stan Lee and John Buscema: This book covers the basics of comic book drawing, including inking, line weight, and design.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
While not anime uniquely, I think the focus on stylization is an important trend.

Historically it was all about capturing reality as realistically as possible, but with cameras and other modern techniques its extremely easy to do that.
For awhile that forced artists to delve into the abstract and other nonsensical forms of expression, but lets be honest, its just a laughable subversion that only got popular because everything thought they were being clever by calling a toilet art.

The focus on stylization such as that seen in anime allows for expression of purpose and ideas. Instead of limiting yourself to drawing things as realistic as possible, you focus primarily on the ideas and concepts you want to show off, and because you don't need to be tied down to the static nature of realistic figures or the inflexible proportions they have, it lets people be more creative with what they're expressing.

Something like pic rel would be completely impossible to replicate by the old masters because real women are ugly and have right feet.

>>6494920
I agree, but less pessimistic about AI being the end of drawing and art. I do think AI will accelerate style trends, generic brands of anime and digital art ('artstation' style) will oversaturate and burn out.
I think we'll return to highly individualistic artist styles. If you look at early American comic strips there was a diversity of styles, from surrealist funny animals to realistic cinematic strips.
The influence of anime/manga is huge. Its effects will be more subtle though (for instance, though I draw in an American style, I'm inspired by the pacing of manga). I think we'll see more international style(s), with artists absorbing all these global influences to develop their quirky styles, with also a return to traditional media to differentiate from the AI behemoth.
Of course, no one has a crystal ball, but history shows that with art every action has a reaction. Artists tend to be very resilient to adapting to changing technology and society, but often in unexpected ways.

>>6490877
It's true that anime has gained popularity and has its own unique style, but to say that it's the "new Renaissance" is an overstatement. The Renaissance was a cultural, historical, and artistic movement that greatly impacted the Western world and set the foundation for modern art. It was a time of great innovation and experimentation in the arts, which had a profound influence on the cultural, political, and social aspects of society.

Anime, on the other hand, is primarily meant to be lighthearted entertainment. It is enjoyed by many for its unique storytelling, colorful characters, and imaginative worlds. While it can contain elements of art, it is not meant to be taken as a serious artistic movement.

posts.name: Royce the Arctic Fox
posts.sub: Art is at the mercy of the artist.
posts.com:
Throughout my decade of drawing I have been through many flies and flops. I made one of my best breakthroughs, and my lowest rock bottoms. And through that roller coaster ride, I have met many artists that has come and gone. And there is one thing to learn about meeting an artist, the art is at the mercy of artists.

Why I say that? Because many times I have met talented artists out that make me question humanity as a whole. Artists that start fights, practices illicit things, or my personal favorite: Being so much of a toxic and narcasistic perfectionists that they lower down anyone that isn't like them or are the very definition of destructive envy (TLDR; John K). But when the artist gets thrown into the spotlight instead of their work, the perception of the artist's craft is forever changed if thrown into the mud.

It wont matter if a man can create the perfect piece of work of all time or the most influential. A man can be literally blessed by God Himself to create the most perfect craft of all, and all it takes is just a moment of bad character to set it all to ash.

I wont say I am innocent. I had my fair share of being a piss poor artist. and when I mean by artist, I mean the person who creates the art. And thankfully I wasn't famous before then, otherwise old immature me would have been screwed over by my immaturity and my own toxic behavior in some places long before I grew out of it. I learned to treat my art style the same way I treat my growth as a person. Mature and polish my mentality and my maturity while getting rid of old habit. That doesn't mean I am free of flaws, I had my fair share of letting flaws get the best of me. But reguardless I still put my best foot foreward as an artist, Lest I be remembered as the disgrace of mankind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6486527
Marks solid. Just stay away from his super autismo takes and just do the line and form drills he outlines. They will serve you well. Do them until you’re proficient and comfortable with them. Don’t obsess over them all day long. Do them when you have a free moment, once a day at least.

No need to overdo it and only do boxes until “mastery” or some retarded shit like that. This is the long game. Just be consistent and do them regularly like an exercise routine, alongside normal drawing.

>>6489436

These three will start you off:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BnLWXmWkHnQ&list=PL1D264418BF4A6BF9&index=2

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JHefdroQdDo

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mk84EpHmZKQ&t=1226s

If you find yourself confused or stuck, go look through his videos and pick a different one about the fundamentals and see if that explains it better. He goes over this same form stuff over and over throughout most of his videos. I finally got it after he drilled it through my head multiple videos later lol.

Remember to practice regularly. Practice making straight lines, circles and all that until it’s smooth. Also be practicing this form stuff he teaches you. Do the drills. They will help you reach the aha moment of understanding form and space.

posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.
>All unsolicited story/series proposals must have a full creative team on board. Writer-only proposals will not be reviewed.

Image comics ( https://imagecomics.com/ )
>Image Comics only publishes creator-owned material. They do not contract creators; they’re only interested in publishing original content for which you would retain all rights.
>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:
> https://jasonthibault.com/definitive-list-comic-publisher-submission-guidelines/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6497881
Hi anon. I mainly make profits from selling my books and original page art at art shows and comic and anime conventions. I fund my print runs with crowdfunding campaigns, and then sell the books for pure profit at shows. My evergreen bestseller is Purrvana, a colorful watercolor painted psychedelic cat graphic novel that appeals to normies of all ages and all demographics from bikers to gangsters to grannies to crazy cat ladies. I have sold over 2,500 copies of Purrvana to date. I also make money from commissions, both my OCs and other people. Most of my commissions are catfight wrestling matches featuring my OCs or other people's OCs. I advertise mainly on pixiv, discord, twitter and my webcomic also works as an advertisement. I also drew animal coloring books years ago that still sell, at shows and online. After a bad experience working with a publisher several years ago, I began self publishing and now that's all I want to do.

I read that Image creators are in the red and go in to debt with Image unless their book sells a certain amount of copies. I recently read tweets from an image artist who says that after his book he worked on sold 5 issues at 15,000 issues each, he only made $1100 in profit and he got paid months after the final issue came out, after the profit share was split with image, the writer and colorist. I don't sell a high volume of copies, and my crowdfunders don't go crazy, but I still make a lot more profit than that Image artist whose book was selling 15,000 copies each issue for example because I keep all the profit of sales for myself. I also do freelance work. Advertising and marketing is not really something I'm good at, but I'm getting by and trying to improve at it. I'm also going to start a life drawing class at my local Junior College next week and I hope it will up my skills so I can charge more for commissions, and it will also improve my comic pages. No rest for the wicked.

As long you have a unique 'twitst' or take on the genre then you'll still stand out in an oversaturated market.
I'd even go as far as say it can be advantageous to use a popular genre/setting like isekai because your audience will immediatly know what to expect.
>"It's an isekai with cool battles, knights, monsters and magic? It's just like the other isekai's I love!"
You can essentially bait an audience and have fun with it by subverting isekai tropes and expectations.
>"that isekai by anon isn't like your average isekai! It looks generic at the beginning but slowly turns into this super deep subversion of the genre. It's fucking peak fiction!"

That's for example the kind of comments isekais like Mushoku Tensei, Re:Zero, Tanya the evil and Konosuba get.
>"It's an isekai but without the shitty writing and blatant power fantasy elements. I swear it's good!"

>but surly everybody can draw competent cartoon characters given a small amount of practice.
Not really more or less than other styles of art. If you're talking stylized cartoons, like >>6498346, you run into the fact that you have to really understand how to draw the character itself, and will find much less assistance from traditional reference material than you would if you were drawing realism, anime, or more human-anatomy influenced cartoons (like Disney). Simply tracing photos won't help crutch your way to a passable result like it can with realism or anime/real-ish cartoons.

There would be no savant syndrome if talent was solely a product of learning and environment. Take Saul Kripke for instance.
